column4: I upgraded to Ubuntu Linux about a week ago. And It was going well. I usually never shut my computer of but when I did I noticed that I had to boot my computer from the flash drive that I had installed Ubuntu on. How can I resolve this issue? I thought I might tell you also that during the setup, the program said it would have to delete two or three partitions (The exact number I can't tell...
...as I can't remember). Also, if it's relevant, I upgraded from Windows 7 to Ubuntu Linux 12.0.4. Can anyone help me resolve this issue?
There is no upgrade path from Windows to Linux at all. And whats the problem at that point - do I get you right that your computer doesnt boot without your flash drive anymore?
Yes.
I used the ISO images on the Ubunto website.
Then you apparently installed ubuntu or the bootloader to the flash drive instead your harddrive.
In the setup, I chose the "Install on hard drive" option. Was it an error on the Ubuntu Installers part or mine?
You were asked where to install the bootloader at the end of the installation.
So, what is the ideal solution in this case?
I guess you have to reinstall, with your flash storage plugged in.
WITHOUT your flash storage plugged in of course.
If that's the case then a Netboot is what I'd have to do, right?
So the flash drive is you installation source?
Yes.
Then you cant remove it, but you have to take care where to install the booit loader at the end of the installation process.
One more thing, How do I login as root on a 12.0.4 Ubuntu system?
There is no root login on Ubuntu. You always log in as a user and then use sudo.
Just curious: What if I were to delete all the files on the jump drive then re-install the ISO image onto it then boot the computer. Would that restart the installation?
No.
You already have a bootable flash drive. Just boot it.
But then how would I get it to reinstall onto my hard drive?
By starting the installation again.
You did it once, you have to do it again.
